Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Correlator product states for quantum chemistry and quantum Monte Carlo
Award.AbstractNarration:
Garnet K. Chan and Cyrus Umrigar of Cornell University are funded by an EAGER award from the Theory, Models and Computational Methods program to explore a novel class of electronic wave functions. Such wave functions have the potential of creating a new quantum chemistry framework enabling studies of electronic structure with global inclusion of electron correlation.

The new approach involves groups of states referred as Correlator Product States (CPS) that are fundamentally different from the wave functions used in established electronic structure approaches such as configuration interaction, coupled cluster, geminal, among others. Initial studies on model systems show that CPS can describe strongly correlated quantum problems more accurately and more efficiently than other classes of wave functions. In this exploratory project the CPS approach is extended to describe dissociation of small molecules and elemental clusters. The new wave functions are very useful as the starting point in diffusion quantum Monte Carlo studies. Currently steps are underway to show that the CPS ansatz provides the framework for understanding an entire class of electronic correlations that are central to transition metal chemistry, excited states, bond-breaking, and complex materials. Broader impacts are achieved by the transformative approach to explore electronic structure studies that affect a broad audience of chemists and material scientists using quantum chemistry and quantum Monte Carlo methodologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Molecular magnets are a class of molecules with potential applications in areas ranging from electronic storage to quantum computing. Although designing better molecular magnets is an important goal, it is difficult to do this in an objective way, as theoretical calculations on the molecules are extremely difficult. The challenge is one that is generic to molecules with a large number of metal atoms: the electrons occupy very similar, i.e. nearly degenerate, energy levels, and thus it is hard to predict their final quantum configuration. On a large computer it is possible without approximation to handle electron configurations of a few metal atoms (say, up to 4), but many molecular magnets have dozens of metal atoms in their structure.

In the funded work, we developed two classes of theoretical techniques to address hard problems of  degenerate electronic structure. The first was based on a new mathematical approximation introduced in the proposal - the correlator product state . In brief, the correlator product state approximation assumes that the overall configuration of the electrons can be deduced by considering only subsets of the electrons at a time, and then patching the results together. We demonstrated the feasibility of this idea by calculating the properties of one of the largest molecular magnets, the so-called giant Keplerate, which has over 30 Fe atoms in it (Fig. 1). We showed that we could accurately predict the magnetic properties and furthermore explain the origins of unusual features observed in the experiments in terms of the underlying orientation of the electronic spins (Fig. 2). Our second achievement was to improve so-called stochastic approaches to electronic structure - which work by sampling the possible electron configurations at random - by 2 orders of magnitude.

The developments in this proposal are of a fundamental scientific nature, but their broader impact lies in the applications that they enable. Metals lie at the heart of many of the most desirable electronic properties that one wishes in a material, such as superconductivity. The ability to accurately describe electronic behaviour in systems with many metals, as advanced by this project, will allow the predictive description, and eventually design, of new classes of materials with such properties.
